title: Cognates & Suffix Patterns
description: You already know 3,000+ French words! Learn 16 suffix conversion patterns to unlock thousands of words overnight.

sections.title: Suffix Conversion Patterns
sections.content: These patterns convert English words to French words with 80-95% accuracy. Memorize these and you unlock thousands of words overnight.

blocks.title: Instant Vocabulary Hack
blocks.body: With just these 16 patterns, you can recognize ~3,000-5,000 French words immediately. When you encounter a new English word with one of these endings, try the French version - you'll be right 80%+ of the time.

title: Pronunciation Rules
description: French spelling looks intimidating, but it follows consistent rules. Learn vowels, nasals, consonants, and the CaReFuL rule.

sections.title: The Golden Rules
sections.content: The 3 most important pronunciation rules in French.

blocks.title: 3 Most Important Pronunciation Rules
bulletPoints: SILENT FINAL CONSONANTS: Most consonants at the end of a word are silent. 'Petit' = puh-TEE. Exception: C, R, F, L (CaReFuL).
STRESS IS ALWAYS ON THE LAST SYLLABLE: Unlike English, French stress is predictable. 'chocolat' = sho-ko-LA.
NASAL VOWELS: When a vowel is followed by N or M (and no vowel after), it becomes nasal. 'bon' = boh(n).

sections.title: Vowel Sounds
sections.content: French vowel sounds and their English approximations.

sections.title: Nasal Vowels
sections.content: These are the sounds that make French sound French. Air goes through your nose.

blocks.title: Nasal Vowel Trick
blocks.body: If a vowel + N/M is followed by ANOTHER VOWEL or another N/M, it's NOT nasal: bonne = BON-nuh (not nasal). But: bon = boh(n) (nasal, because N is at the end).

sections.title: Consonant Tricks
sections.content: French consonant rules and their quirks.

sections.title: The CaReFuL Rule
sections.content: Most final consonants are silent, but C, R, F, L are usually pronounced.

title: Gender Rules
description: Every French noun is masculine or feminine. Learn patterns that let you guess correctly 80%+ of the time.

sections.title: Feminine Endings
sections.content: Endings that are almost always feminine (la).

blocks.title: Gender Survival Strategy
blocks.body: Learn gender WITH the word: never learn 'maison' alone. Learn 'la maison'. When in doubt, -tion/-sion/-te/-ure patterns cover HUNDREDS of words and are almost always right.

sections.title: Masculine Endings
sections.content: Endings that are almost always masculine (le).

title: Verb Conjugation
description: French verbs seem terrifying, but there are massive shortcuts. Learn the 27 essential verbs and conjugation patterns.

sections.title: Essential Verbs
sections.content: For NCLC 5 conversation, you need about 30 verbs that cover 80%+ of daily situations.

sections.title: Spoken French Shortcut
sections.content: For ALL regular -er verbs, je, tu, and il/elle forms are pronounced IDENTICALLY.

blocks.title: Conjugation Shortcut
blocks.body: je parle, tu parles, il/elle parle = all pronounced 'PARL'. For spoken French, you only need 4 sounds per verb: je/tu/il (same), nous, vous, ils/elles.

sections.title: Present Tense Patterns
sections.content: 80% of French verbs end in -er and follow a simple pattern.

sections.title: Future Tense Cheat
sections.content: Use 'aller + infinitive' instead of learning the formal future tense.

sections.title: Past Tense Cheat
sections.content: The passe compose formula: Subject + avoir (conjugated) + past participle.

blocks.title: DR. & MRS. VANDERTRAMP
blocks.body: About 15 verbs use etre instead of avoir in the past tense. These are mostly verbs of MOVEMENT. With etre, the past participle agrees with the subject.

title: Essential Grammar
description: Negation, questions, articles, and contractions - the essential grammar patterns.

sections.title: Negation
sections.content: To make any sentence negative, put NE...PAS around the conjugated verb.

blocks.title: Spoken French Shortcut
blocks.body: In everyday spoken French, the 'ne' is almost always DROPPED: Je parle pas. Il mange pas. C'est pas vrai.

title: Numbers

sections.title: Numbers 70-99
sections.content: The infamous French number system: 70 = 60+10, 80 = 4x20, 90 = 4x20+10.

blocks.title: Belgian & Swiss French
blocks.body: In Belgian & Swiss French: 70 = septante, 80 = huitante/octante, 90 = nonante. Much simpler!

blocks.title: The #1 TEF Speaking Secret
blocks.body: The examiner isn't grading your grammar perfection. They're grading your ability to COMMUNICATE. A confident speaker who makes mistakes but keeps talking will ALWAYS score higher than a hesitant speaker with perfect sentences but long silences. Keep. Talking.
